A running crawler may create many logs of its ongoing activity. 
Some of the logs may capture individual transactions or errors;
others may capture summaries of the crawler state/progress at
specific times.

For example, Mercator has transactional logs of:
 - each checkpoint (chkptLog.txt)
 - dns errors (dns-errors.######)
 - java exceptions thrown (errors.######)
 - robots.txt rules fetches (robotsLog.######)
 - every URL visited (timings.######)

Mercator has state/progress logs of:
 - overall progress/rates per ~10 second period (crawl-log.txt)
 - http status code totals per checkpoint (http-status-histo.log)
 - queue lengths per checkpoint (Q.log)

Some weaknesses of the Mercator logs are that not all of them
are timestamped, and some have multi-line-per-record formats
less amenable to automated processing than would be ideal.

For Heritrix, we would like to define logging practices which
make post-crawl analysis as easy as possible. 

Some general principles:

* The log info that is most commonly summed/merged/sorted/etc
  should be one-record-per-line, with fields whitespace-delimited. 
  (If a field value needs to have whitespace within it, we may
  allow double-quoted fields.)

* Every such log line will begins with a digit character; more 
  specifically, a datestamp, of the form YYYYMMDDHHMMSS[mmm].

* Info other than log lines may also appear in log files,
  such as an explanatory header/legend, internal comments, or 
  annotations of line info that would be awkward to squeeze
  into the single line. This other info appears in lines
  which never begin with a digit character. 

* Legend lines, specifically, begin with a ":" character, and 
  list field names in their relative positions. 

With this in mind, the core logs for Heritrix (without 
considering eventual checkpointing):

 - uri-processing.log

   Per-URI disposition, such as success or failure. 
   Roughly equivalent to Mercator's "timings" + 
   "dns-error" (since DNS lookups are treated as
   any other URIs).

 - crawl-progress.log
 
   Sampling of crawler state/progress at configurable
   intervals; like Mercator's "crawl-log".

 - crawl-errors.log

   Serious errors, such as unhandled exceptions 
   conditions that cannot be retried/classified as
   a matter of policy. 

 - uri-errors.log

   URIs which are discovered but are too problematic to
   crawl.

Tentative formats for each:

uri-processing.log

[timestamp] [status-code] [length] [URI] [mime-type] 

crawl-progress.log

(exactly as in Mercator's crawl-log, namely:)

[timestamp] [discovered-pages] [pending-pages] [downloaded-pages] [unique-pages] \
 [overall-docs-per-sec] [current-docs-per-sec] [overall-KB-sec] [current-KB-sec] \
 [download-failures] [stalled-threads] [memory-usage]

crawl-errors.log

[timestamp] [URI-if-possible] [error-message-if-available]
...and on subsequent non-timestamped lines, arbitrary other
info, such as a stack dump.

uri-errors.log

[timestamp] [source-URI] [error-message-if-available] [problem-URI]
